subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: Lesotho has set neither a net-zero emissions goal nor a long-term carbon strategy.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Lesotho has submitted a business-as-usual (BAU) target which intends to lower its greenhouse gas emissions by 10% by 2030. If it receives external support (finance, investment), it intends to increase its commitment by 25%. With this, the total emission reduction would be of 35% to be achieved by 2030.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: There is no fossil fuel phase-out policy in Lesotho.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: The Lesotho Energy Policy (2015-2025) provides a strategy for the energy sector but has not been formally adopted, creating uncertainty over the status and plan for the sector. A draft renewable energy framework policy has also been developed, including mechanisms for procuring both off-grid and on-grid renewable energy, but this has not been adopted either. The country has set an electricity-access target of 40% of the population by 2020 and they have succeeded.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Some 90 megawatts of renewables are under development, with power offtake agreements in place. The 20-megawatt NEO1 Solar project has been financed by the African Development Bank/World Bank, and the 70-megawatt NEO2 Solar project has been financed and developed by China’s Exim bank. When completed, they will more than double Lesotho's fleet size. Lesotho attracted $16 million for solar projects in 2019, the only investment seen in a decade.

Power prices are extremely high in Lesotho, with pricing increasing between 8% and 8.34% for all customer categories. Lesotho has elevated prices by the need to procure imports from South Africa. A growing domestic fleet, with low marginal-cost electricity, should help reduce local power prices.

subsections.title: Power market
text: Lesotho's current installed capacity features 76 megawatts of hydro. In 2018, Lesotho imported 30% of its power from neighboring South Africa. While its domestic fleet is composed entirely of hydro, South Africa's grid is composed of 90% coal power. Between its domestic production and imports, Lesotho's average carbon intensity is about 0.218 CO2 kg/KWh. Expansion of its domestic fleet with renewable energy will reduce import volumes and lower the carbon footprint of the power sector. The country has a strong financial incentive to do so, as imported electricity costs 10 times as much as domestically produced power.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Data indicates that Lesotho's electrification rate has advanced from 17% in 2015 to almost 45% in 2020. Lesotho's energy-access goals stipulate continued growth toward 50% by 2022, and 80% by 2030. This would provide a substantial opportunity for investment in the power sector.

Confusion is created by a number of overlapping energy-sector entities, including the Department of Energy, Lesotho Electricity Co., Lesotho Energy and Water Authority and Rural Electrification Unit, which results in an underdeveloped regulatory framework, a lack of equipment technical standards and slow implementation of energy-sector projects. There is also limited availability of suitable land for renewable energy development. The terrain is mountainous, and access is difficult, and where it is accessible it is often already used for agriculture or settlement.

subsections.title: EV market
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The road transport sector has been developing since the 1970’s and has currently extended even into the remotest areas of the country. Lesotho development has been influenced by the extension of road networks across the whole country through government initiatives.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: The Lesotho government recognizes the importance of giving attention to the effective and efficient use of energy and aims to target its strategies in the following demand-related areas: households, industry and commerce, government, and transport. Until now, any substantive policy support in this sector and the low-carbon heat market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the low-carbon heat market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The law in Lesotho requires public utilities to obtain government-issued letter of guarantee as a prerequisite before a loan is granted.
